ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminar
We had guests visit for virtual guest lectures and performances.
We attended guest speaker lectures in an interview format led by the professor, in addition to a student Q&A.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about comedy as a form and discussed issues of representation, audience, satire -- all with how it intersects with race
I think my major take-away from this course is broadly how racial structures permeate, are (de)constructed by, and are negotiated through comedy.
I learned about how to analyze and think critically about comedy and different mediums of humor. I strengthened my writing and presentation skills while gaining a new perspective on the world.
I learned how to look at racial & racialized comedy critically, and engaged with different comedic media.

To my knowledge this is the only Yale course that focuses on comedy studies, or at least from a critical ethnic studies angle. I gained a lot of new insights into comedy studies, and I feel like I'm going to be even more well equipped to analyze culture. I learned theoretical approaches to comedy and some relevant histories of US comedy.

We learned how race and comedy intersect. Very few academic courses in general focus on comedy so it was very refreshing to explore how comedy has been used to perpetuate stereotypes and other negative caricatures in the United States.

I gained an understanding of how the American history of racism is inextricable from the American history of comedy. Learned how to critically watch, analyze, and write about standup performances, TV episodes, and other forms of entertainment that i had previously watched with a less discerning eye.
It was good to think about comedy analytically and as an analytic.

This course teaches you to think critically about popular culture, with a particular angle on comedy. You analyze literature, stand up, film, and sitcoms in a way that is pretty novel to usual AMST/ER&M courses.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: strengths: variety of content each week (readings usually paired with a video/movie/etc), Prof. Laguna's support and help throughout the semester, fun content; weaknesses: none
I really enjoyed the flow, the consistency of the work, and the vibe.

Strengths: This class used a variety of media, which was really helpful in an all-virtual semester. The readings were never overwhelming; they were always very doable and interesting. The assignments were doable and interesting. Prof Laguna did a good job of creating a comfortable class environment, where we could feel comfortable just chatting or coming to him whenever we had a problem.

Weaknesses: There was rarely time for the entire class to engage the material. The bulk of the class was spent in small groups, and there was never enough time to regroup after. I think a break in the middle of the class would have been quite helpful as well. It became very hard for me to stay engaged by the end of the two-hour class, just sitting at my computer. A three-minute bathroom/stretch break would have been really nice. The grading was also not super transparent; we never received discussion grades, participation grades, or grades on our presentations, so it was hard to know exactly where we stood.

Professor Laguna is a really kind and caring professor, which is great during covid especially. Although he did start out the year with hefty assignments (like weekly responses) he toned these down over the semester as he saw how engaged we were even though the class was virtual.
No weaknesses. The class is organized fantastically for student learning and class engagement. 10/10 class.
The range of course material and readings was a strength: we read theoretical texts and novels, watched films and standup specials, and also saw a live performance.

Like a lot of ethnic studies classes, Race and Comedy has some weeks for different minorities (e.g. Asian Am comedy week, Latinx comedy). I would have liked to learn about Indigenous comedy. The biggest strength of the course is that it's just interesting--pop culture is just interesting and it's therefore super interesting to academically study pop culture. This is huge for me too--the syllabus is really well-weighted, meaning there aren't two assignments that constitute 85% of the grade like a lot of seminar classes have (e.g. final paper will be worth 50% of the grade). It gives you a lot of room throughout the semester to do well. Laguna is very accommodating and it's obvious that he knew how hard the semester was for basically everybody because he modified our final assignment in our interests. He also did a good job picking people for the class (I think it's fairly selective since the topic is clickbait-y not in a bad way). People had thoughtful takes and were willing to participate over Zoom. As for weaknesses, I think it was unclear how we were doing in the class at any given point. But then again you could just go to office hours and ask him, I guess.
It was refreshing to have a good reading load with films to balance out other reading courses I was taking.

Strengths 
- Appreciated the weekly response post to readings. because they were due the night before class, they helped me gather my thoughts in preparation for discussion and develop my understanding of whatever element of the homework that I was most personally struck by. 

- Class discussions were always enriching, largely because the material itself was so fascinating. We covered a large amount of material, but i never felt that we rushed through anything. 

-Guest lectures were amazing, even given the Zoom constraints. 

Weaknesses
-Sometimes felt that the professor couldve connected the various weeks better, tying together topics that were not on their face interrelated, in order to develop a more coherent narrative.
Professor Laguna is a fantastic instructor and discussion facilitator, though I wish there had been more feedback on assignments from either him or the TF.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: being on zoom for two hours at a time is a lot but Prof. Laguna made it enjoyable with ice breakers at the beginning of each seminar
I would really like to see some use of polls (PollEverywhere or Zoom Polls), but I really appreciated the songs at the beginning!
Movie and TV show assignments work well, virutally.

The opening of the class being light was great but the long break out sessions felt a bit much. I feel like the class would have been better served if we were having a discussion with all 16 of us rather than in groups of 4 because there are naturally more opinions and perspectives and the professor can guide the conversation.

I loved how Professor Laguna took the first 15 minutes of every class to just chat and get to know one another, it was a kind effort to rekindle the socialness of seminars that has been lost to zoom and it was very effective in bringing the class together.
The breakout rooms actually really went well and I always had lively discussions
Successful leading of Zoom seminars. Really appreciated that the material for our homework was varied (readings, videos, podcasts), which provided a nice reprieve from the rigors of online school.
Final assignment reduction
Prof Laguna made sure to give us a mix of texts outside of just readings, and it's something the class really appreciated.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! The syllabus is well balanced and Prof. Laguna is a wonderful instructor. The content is fun and engaging
ABSOLUTELY! Anyone who likes comedy should take this class. I think it has such broad implications and I can never look at comedy in the same way.
Absolutely!! Take this class if you have a chance!! Laguna is amazing, the content is SO interesting, the assignments are winging, and overall you will learn a lot and have fun while doing it.
Yes, the topics in this course are engaging and relevant, and the class is a lot of fun.

I would. It doesn't feel that strenuous because we're analyzing fun things. I liked how assignments were relatively evenly weighted throughout the semester. Don't be afraid to disagree with others in the class, including Prof Laguna, and don't be afraid to assert yourself. I think that's the most important thing I could say. If we think of our classes as providing useful frameworks and tools for the way we approach the world, then we don't need to agree with the class or professor 100% in order to get something out of it. (this goes for all classes)
Yes! Youll get a lot of information out of the course.

Absolutely, if you are at all interested in critical race theory, the history of race relations in America, or any form of comedy.  There is a place for everyone in the class, whether you come in knowing very much about one of these topics and little about the others or just being curious about all of them with no prior background knowledge.
I definitely would recommend this class to anyone interested in learning how to be a scholar of popular culture.
